snippet: Nearly half say that the city is a worse place to live under the mayor’s watch, and 51 percent say New York is now less safe, even as crime statistics reach historic lows.
abstract: Poll conducted by New York Times and Siena College finds that 59 percent of white people living in New York disapprove of Mayor Bill de Blasio's performance, up sharply from start of his term; mayor’s advisers are now making concerted efforts to recapture support in fear that group will rally around challenger in 2017.

byline.original: By MICHAEL M. GRYNBAUM, ALEXANDER BURNS and DALIA SUSSMAN
byline.contributor: Megan Thee-Brenan and Marina Stefan contributed reporting.

lead_paragraph: Nearly half say that the city is a worse place to live under the mayor’s watch, and 51 percent say New York is now less safe, even as crime statistics reach historic lows.

headline.main: Mayor de Blasio Has Lost Support of White New Yorkers, Poll Finds
headline.print_headline: New Poll Shows Mayor Has Lost Whites’ Support
